metadata.title: Identification of interfacial transition zone in asphalt concrete based on nano-scale metrology techniques

sections.text:

(interfacial transition zone, ITZ) is very helpful in understanding some mechanisms that govern the fracture behavior of asphalt pavement. However, it is rather difficult to identify and study ITZ by bulk techniques. In this study, nano-scale metrology techniques, including nanoindentation (NI), field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM), and energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS), were employed to explore the micromechanics, microstructure, and chemical properties of ITZ. Experimental results show that the ITZ exists in asphalt mixture and the thickness of ITZ is in the range from 5 μm to 20 μm. The modulus value of ITZ was found between that of the aggregate and the mastic. The microstructure of ITZ was observed to be more compacted than that of mastic. This study contributes significantly to the nano-scale characterization of ITZ in asphalt concrete, which can provide more realist inputs for the micromechanical models. Key words: interfacial transition zone; asphalt mixture; nanoindentation; energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS); image processing technique.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Mechanisms of interactions at asphalt-aggregate interface are of vital importance because
the asphalt must adhere to the aggregate for the adhesive binding action to keep the aggregate particles and hence pavement together. During the mixing and compaction process, when fillers coated by asphalt binders are suspended in the mix (asphalt mastic comes into being) and they get into very close vicinity of a much large aggregate particle, then physical, chemical, and mechanical actions may occur between the mastic and aggregate material, leading to a narrow region formed around the aggregate particles. This region can be called as the interfacial transition zone (ITZ).
Identifying the nature of the region where the mastic meets the aggregate surface is very
helpful in understanding some mechanisms that govern the fracture behavior of asphalt pavement, since this region is always recognized as a weak link, whose strength are relatively low. Matzenmiller and Gerlanch found that the interfacial bond strength has an effect on the overall behavior of composite materials [1]. The research of He et al. showed that the fiber/matrix interfacial properties change the dominant fiber failure type from rupture to pull-out mode, and thus affect the strain-hardening behavior [2]. Wang et al. gave that if the bonding between two materials is unstable, or there is some damage at the interface, composites cannot be used properly [3]. To improve the mechanical strength of composites, some special additives were also

studied and applied to enhance the interlocking effect between two different composites. For instance, Cui et al. used carbon nanotubes to enhance the interaction of carbon shish-kebab with polyimide [4]. As a result, the composite exhibits higher strength than composite without carbon nanotubes. There is a significant amount of researches on the bonding strength of interfacial zone between asphalt binder and aggregates. As pointed by Mo et al., the adhesive zone, where the mortar meets the stone surface, can be represented as a system consisting of two stone columns with a thin bitumen film in between [5]. Based on the adhesive zone fatigue test and mortar fatigue test, Mo concluded that the adhesive zone between stone and mortar tends to be the weak link in the stone contact region [6]. Moreover, the weak link is responsible for raveling [7]. Qudis and Al-Shweily investigated the effect of aggregate properties on asphalt mixtures stripping and showed that the strength bond between aggregates and bitumen differs in different conditions[8]. Horgnies et al. studied the influence of the interfacial composition on the adhesion between aggregates and bitumen and found that limestone tends to form a strong bond with bitumen in comparison with granite because of their mineral composition [9]. On the contrary, Zhang et al. investigated the cohesive and adhesive strength of bitumen-aggregate samples and found that granite aggregate tends to produce a higher bonding strength than limestone aggregates in dry conditions when adhesive failure occurs [10].
ITZ exists at length scales as small as a few micrometers. The thickness of ITZ in
cement-based materials is different in different researches. For instance, Zimbelmann found the thickness of ITZ ranged from 10 μm to about 30 μm [11]. Ollivier et al. argued that there was only thickness of 15 μm to 20 μm around the aggregates [12]. For the fiber-mortar interface, most observations suggested a relatively large porous and weak layer on the order of 40 μm to 70 μm thickness [13]. For the ITZ around steel reinforcement, it showed that the thickness varied from 10 μm to 40 μm [14]. The interfacial transition zone was detected in a thickness of 20 μm to 30 μm between brick and matrix [15]. The ITZ appears as the “weakest link” in the concrete, so the influence of ITZs on mechanical behavior of overall concrete remains an interesting research topic. Scrivener et al. observed that the changes are progressive and are most significant in the first 15 μm to 20 μm closest to the aggregates according to the scanning electron microscope images [16]. With the consideration of ITZ in width of 15 μm to 30 μm, Königsberger et al. investigated the stresses within and around the ITZ by theoretical and analytical method and found that micromechanics model allows for upscaling this microscopic failure behavior to concrete-level criteria for crack initiation [17]. Skarżyński et al. investigated the cracking process in concrete by experiments and finite element methods and concluded that the crack mainly propagated though ITZs. In this study, the thickness of ITZ is accounted as 30 μm to 50 μm [18]. Similarly, Suchorzewski et al. studied the concrete fracture by experiments and discrete element simulations and found that the numerical model is capable of accurately predicting mechanical responses observed in experiments . However, the width of ITZs in this study was found to be merely 2 μm to 3 μm that is significantly smaller than in usual concrete, which results from a very smooth aggregate surface [19]. Due to the ITZ appears as the “weakest link” in concrete, the ITZ has been taken into account especially in the building of a meso-scale model of concrete. Gitman et al. proposed a multi-scale model with ITZ to accurately describe the behavior of concrete [20]. Skarzynski and Tejchman developed a meso-scale numerical model with ITZ to analyze strain localization in concrete [21]. Kim and Al-Rub conducted meso-scale simulations to investigate the contribution of ITZ to the strength and damage response of concrete [22]. Skarzynski et al.

carried out comprehensive numerical analyses to investigate fracture process in concrete by developing a 2D meso-scale model with ITZ [23]. Likewise, with the aim of simulating the fracture process of concrete, Trawinski et al. built a discrete element model in which the ITZs was considered [24]. In view of asphalt concrete, the research on thickness of ITZs is till vacant based on the experimental observation. Fortunately, there are some micromechanical models available to be adopted to predict the effect of ITZ on the micromechanical behavior of asphalt concrete. Generally, in asphalt concrete, there are two different models to simulate the ITZ. One is the interphase model, which introduces a thin layer of a third material with the specified thickness between the inclusion and matrix material. For instance, Huang et al. introduced an intermediate layer in a three-layer HMA model and found that stress concentration was reduced after introducing a stiffer intermediate layer [25]. Another approach is to model the ITZ as a spring layer, which means the tractions are continuous across the interface while the displacement jumps are allowed from aggregate to mastic. For instance, Zhu et al. established a micromechanical model with imperfect interface to predict the elastic and viscoelastic behavior of asphalt concrete and suggested that the interface effect must be considered when establish the numerical or analytical model to study asphalt concrete [26, 27].
ITZ differs in chemistry and microstructure from the mastic and inclusion phases, but its
properties vary with the characteristics of aggregate particle and asphalt both. Since each of the aggregates introduces different sizes, surface textures, and surface chemistry, heterogeneity of the aggregates definitely results in the different active surface sites that are available for interaction with asphalt molecules. Besides, chemical properties of asphalts from different source crude oils will also differ from each other, which make the ITZ properties much more complicated. Cui et al. found that granite shows less adhesion ability than limestone and marble especially under wet conditions [28]. Tan and Guo maintained that the interface interactions between asphalt and different fillers are ranked in the following order: granite>andesite>limestone [29]. Liu et al. and Grenfell et al. both suggested that limestone aggregate presents a better adhesive bond with bitumen than granite aggregate based on rolling bottle test and surface energy test [30, 31]. Cong et al. thought that the adhesion between asphalt binder and limestone or basalt is higher than that between asphalt binder and diabase or sandstone according to surface free energy analysis [32]. Although there is significant number of studies focused on adhesion between asphalt and aggregates, until now, no consensus has been reached because of the unclear properties of ITZ.
Actually, the interface interaction mechanism between them incorporates chemisorption,
physisorption, and mechanical interlocking [33, 34]. If the aggregate has a smooth surface and no strongly chemical reaction occurred between the aggregate and mastic, the van der Waals forces become dominant for collecting very fine-grained small particles. Usually, the van der Waals forces operating between asphalt and aggregate could be estimated by using of contact angle and vapor sorption measurement techniques [35, 36]. Another situation, when there is still no apparent chemical reaction happened, but the surfaces of the aggregates are rugose, the adhesion between asphalt mastic and aggregate may mainly result from some combination of mechanical interlocking. Despite of above asphalt-aggregate bond mechanisms, the third situation originates from chemical adsorption, which plays a vital role. The molecular structures of asphalt binder can be categorized into asphaltenes, resins, aromatics, and saturates. Asphaltenes are highly polar components that account for 5-25 percent of asphalt binder, and

resins are semi-solid polar materials. Both of them can trigger the formation of chemical bonds between asphalt binders and aggregates, especially during the hot-mix process due to the extremely high temperature. Normally, the chemical adhesion strength is much stronger than physisorption and mechanical interlocking strength and significantly affects long-term bond durability between the asphalt and aggregate surface. Nevertheless, in most situations, three main bonding mechanisms, namely chemisorption, physisorption, and mechanical interlocking, as shown in Fig. 1, work as a combined action to influence the ultimate adhesive strength of ITZ. Since ITZ is such a tiny zone and its strength formation mechanisms are so complicated, until now, no evident materials can be found to identify or even support the existence of ITZ in asphalt mixture.
Fig. 1 Bonding mechanisms occurred in interfacial transition zone
However, with the emergence of nanoindentation technology, it is now possible to directly
measure the nano-mechanical properties of ITZ. The nanoindentation (NI) technique is similar to classical indentation, but is capable of producing contact areas and penetration depths on submicron or nanoscales. Moreover, coupling nano-mechanical testing with transmission electron microscope (TEM) can establish a one-to-one relationship between load-depth characteristics and stress-induced microstructure evolution, namely, monitoring the material’s microstructure in real time throughout the test. Kong et al. investigated influence of nano-silica agglomeration on microstructure improvement of the hardened cement-based materials through NI technique and found that the large agglomerates may become weak zones due to their low strength and elastic modulus [37]. Vandamme and Ulmassessed explored the creep properties of calcium silicate hydrates (C-S-H) by means of NI technique creep experiments and observed that the measured creep compliance of C-S-H is very well captured by a logarithmic time function [38]. Moser et al. studied the fundamental material behaviors and failure mechanisms of cement based materials by NI technique and concluded that several factors degrade both the elastic modulus and indentation hardness of ultra-high performance concretes [39]. As for the application of NI used in asphalt materials, Tareder et al. studied the hardness and elastic modulus of asphalt materials [40]; Hossain et al. explored the effects of moisture in mastic materials using nanoindentation [41]; Veytskin et al. investigated the viscoelasticity of asphalt

binder and mastic [42]. Besides, considering the fact that the ITZ of asphalt mixture has not been visualized experimentally, Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) is another increasingly popular tool for studying ITZ. Scrivener et al. analyzed the microstructure of ITZ in concrete by a large numbers of backscattered electron images [43]. Anna et al. studied the interface between aggregates and cement paste by SEM and found that the nature of aggregate and w/c ratio determines the micro structural characteristics of the aggregate-cement paste interface [44]. Xie et al. investigated the effects of different factors on the properties of the ITZ of rock filled concrete by SEM and NI technique [45]. The chemical characterizations of ITZ can be revealed qualitatively by acquiring the backscattered electron (BSE) image and secondary electron (SE) image via SEM. Meanwhile, Energy-dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) is one of fast techniques for X-ray elemental analysis. For example, elemental analysis across the ITZ can be performed in a “line mode”.
The main scope of this study is to investigate the ITZ of asphalt concrete in submicrometer
or nanometer dimensions. To achieve this goal, a unique measurements of micromechanical properties of asphalt concrete was put forward. Experiments of nanoindentation, SEM, and EDS were performed on the ITZ to give an illustration on mechanical properties of ITZ, thickness of ITZ, microstructure of ITZ, and chemical constitute of ITZ in asphalt concrete. In addition, the ITZ of asphalt concrete with different aggregates was compared and discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1 Asphalt mixtures preparation
sections.text:
The pen 60/80 virgin asphalt binder, produced by China National Offshore Oil Corp., was
used in this study. The properties, such as penetration, softening point and ductility, of this asphalt binder are listed in Table 1. The aggregate used was limestone with a density of 2.706 g/cm3. The density of mineral filler was 2.667 g/cm3, with 94.5% by mass greater than 0.075mm. Four fractions of aggregates were used, including 9.5-19 mm, 4.75-9.5 mm, 2.36-4.75 mm and 0-2.36 mm. The four fractions of aggregates were used for designing aggregates gradation of AC-20 asphalt mixture, and the combined gradation of blended aggregates is shown in table 2. To investigate the effect of aggregates on ITZ, the size of 4.75-9.5mm bottom ash aggregates and basalt aggregates were employed. They were used as partial substitutes for 4.75-9.5mm limestone aggregates. To assure other components’ contents remained unchanged, the proportion of replacement was only 2% by mass. It should be mentioned that the bottom ash aggregate is the output from the municipal solid waste incineration (MSWI) residues, which contains brick, glass, metal, ceramic and slag. The densities of bottom ash aggregates and basalt aggregates with the size of 4.75-9.5mm were 2.412 g/cm3 and 2.905 g/cm3, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2 Samples prepared for nano-scale tests
sections.text:
Firstly, the Marshall specimen was prepared, and the cross section of Marshall specimen is
shown in Fig. 2(a). Secondly, the Marshall specimen was cut into the cube, whose size was 15mm×15mm×15mm. Then, the cube was embedded in the epoxy resin, as shown in Fig. 2(b). The specimen’s surface was further ground and polished to make the top surface parallel with the bottom surface, so as to ensure no tilt indentation happens. The specimen was ground on 180, 600, 1200, 2500, 5000 grit abrasive paper one by one and polished on a polishing cloth further. The polishing process took about 2 hours until the entire surface had been ground thoroughly. Finally, the specimen was cleaned in an ultrasonic bath for 5 min. It is important to consider the surface roughness of a specimen because it is related to the measurement accuracy. In order to investigate the ITZ in asphalt mixture, the test area containing the aggregate, ITZ, and mastic was chosen, as shown in Fig. 2(c) and Fig. 2(d). The test area is 100 μm100 μm. The distance of adjacent points in a horizontal line is 5 μm and the distance between two test points in a longitudinal line is 10μm. As a result, the total test points are 231.
Fig. 2 Hierarchical structure diagrams of test area

sections.heading: 2.3.3 Loading mode for NI test
sections.text:
be determined according to the properties of materials. The mastic exhibits viscoelasticity, however, the aggregates tend to be elastic. Therefore, it is necessary to conduct partial unloading tests on mastic and aggregates before determining the load mode. The partial unloading test is a typical nanoindentation test cycle consisting of an application of load followed by an unloading sequence. Here, the indenter experienced 33 load increments to reach the peak loading of 8000 μN and 70% partial unloading was programed in each load increment, which can be illustrated in Fig. 6. The final depth is about 250 nm at the maximum force of 8000 μN in the aggregate, 600 nm in the ITZ, 5000 nm at the force of 5000 μN in the mastic (see Figs. 7, 8, 9). This result indicates that if under the load control mode, the indentation depth will be very different in mastic, ITZ and aggregates because of the different mechanical properties among them. Thus the depth control mode is suggested in this study. Due to the maximum force the nanoindentation equipment allowed is 10 mN, the indentation depth in the aggregate should be below 300 nm based on Fig. 7. Besides, it has been shown that the indentation depth should be larger than the RMS roughness [51]. Considering the RMS of the mastic, the indentation depth should be larger than 127.03 nm. In addition, to avoid a mutual influence, the distance between two adjacent test points should be at least 20 times as long as their final depth. Therefore, the indentation depth should be below 250 nm since the distance between two adjacent points was set as 5 μm in this study. Based on the above analysis, the maximum indentation depth is set as 200 nm.

After that, the load was held at its maximum for 2 s before unloading at the same constant rate. The protocol for the movement from one test point to the next was set as a Constant Direction Mode.

It can be seen that the p-h curves can characterize the mastic, ITZ and aggregate perfectly, and different regions can be well distinguished, which indicates that the surface roughness and loading mode are all meet the requirements of NI test.

sections.heading: 2.4 FESEM and EDS
sections.text:
The first sentence in Section 2.4 has been revised as the follows: The sample was also
analyzed by field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) equipped with secondary electron detectors coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). The FESEM-EDS provides detailed imaging individual phase, as well as elemental composition of samples.
FESEM is one of the best and most widely used techniques for the chemical and physical
characterization of materials. FESEM, using a focused electron beam to scan the surface of a
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
sample, generates a variety of signals. The most common modes of operation in FESEM analysis are backscattered electron imaging (BSE) and secondary electron imaging (SE). BSE provides visual information based on gray-scale intensity between chemical phases. Backscattered electrons are high-energy electrons that are reflected directly from the specimen surface. The quantity of electrons backscattered correlates to the atomic number. This generates a contrast between phases of different atomic numbers that can easily be distinguished in the backscattered electron image. Secondary electrons are also the main means of viewing images in the FESEM because the large depth of field enables 3D images to be obtained. EDS has been extensively used as a chemical microanalysis technique to determine the elemental composition of materials. It relies on an interaction of some source of X-ray excitation and a sample. Its characterization capabilities are due in large part to the fundamental principle that each element has a unique atomic structure allowing unique set of peaks on its X-ray emission spectrum.
In this study, FESEM (Nova NanoSEM 450) with EDS (EDAX GENESIS XM series) was carried
out to characterize the ITZ and examine the elements variation across the ITZ. The sample was studied in the secondary electron imaging mode. All analysis was performed at 15 KV beam acceleration potential, and beam incidence was normal to the surface with a working distance of 8 mm. The elemental analysis was performed in a “line mode” in which the electron beam is scanned point by point across the ITZ. The EDS images were taken with dwell time of 0.1 m/s and 30 sweep times at 512 × 384 pixels.

sections.heading: 3.1 Nano-scale mechanical properties
sections.text:
The elastic moduli were acquired from the nanoindentation tests, then the data were used
to generate a two dimensional contour map of indentation modulus in the tested region, as shown in Fig. 11. The deep blue area shows the lowest modulus, which indicates the soft mastic. The red area shows the highest modulus, which indicates the aggregate. The green area located in the regions between aggregates and mastic demonstrates the existence of ITZ in asphalt mixture.
Fig. 11 The contour map of elastic modulus
To characterize the mechanical properties of ITZ, the acquired data were subsequently

statistically analyzed. Figure 12 shows the probability distribution of indentation modulus. It is observed that the data can be mainly separated into three parts, namely 0-10 GPa, 10-50 GPa, and 50-100 GPa. Combined with the contour map of elastic modulus shown in Fig. 11, mastic, ITZ and aggregates can be well identified. For example, the data located in 0-10 GPa represent the modulus of mastic, 10-50 GPa represent the modulus of ITZ and 50-110 GPa represent the modulus of aggregates. To observe the ITZ region more clearly in the contour map, 50 GPa was set as a boundary value. The values which are larger than 50 GPa are all set as 50 GPa. The processed values were mapped in Fig. 13. In this figure, a thicker ITZ is found at the pore-structure area, whereas a thinner ITZ is observed at an even surface, which means the pore structure plays a role on the thickness of ITZ.
Fig. 12 The distribution diagram of elastic modulus
Fig. 13 The processed contour map of elastic modulus
Besides, the morphology of ITZ can be distinguished distinctly in the contour map. The
thickness of ITZ is varied in the range of 5 μm to 20 μm, which is smaller than the thickness of ITZ in cementitious materials (range from 10 μm to 70 μm). However, based on the micromechanical prediction results in Refs. [52, 53] , the asphalt film thickness is in the range of 5 μm to 15 μm, which are quite similar to our test results. It is known that a suitable thickness of asphalt film beyond the aggregate surface contributes to improve pavement performance. However, so far there is no research demonstrating the morphology, mechanical and chemical properties of asphalt film. Especially, the thickness and constitute of asphalt film remain an enigma since asphalt film is such a tiny area that could not be verified by conventional tests. To get the

morphological and mechanical properties of asphalt film, we conducted NI test on a specified district where two aggregates are surrounded by the asphalt film (see Fig. 14). The modulus mapping is shown in Fig. 15. It can be seen that the elastic modulus of asphalt film is lower than the surrounding aggregates. However, the elastic modulus of asphalt film between two aggregates is much higher than asphalt binder’s. Particularly, the mean modulus of the blue area is about 3 GPa, whereas the modulus of pure asphalt binder is in the range of tens to hundreds MPa depending on the temperature. It is speculated that the asphalt film may be a combination of asphalt binder and fillers or fine aggregates. This speculation can be explained by Fig. 1. The chemical bonding, electrostatic force, wet adhesion and mechanical interlocking may contribute to the formation of a more dense structure around the aggregate surface (this dense structure may the combination of asphalt binder and fillers, and the fillers’ size is within nano-scale or no more than a few micrometers). That’s why the elastic modulus of the area with dense structure around the aggregate’s surface is higher than the elastic modulus of the area far away from the aggregate’s surface (asphalt mastic). The dense structure area with the thickness of 5 μm to 20 μm, which is different from the traditional concept of asphalt film, was called ITZ in this study.

The whole information handled by image processing technique is listed in Table 4. In Table 5, it can be seen that the mean force obtained in the aggregate is the highest,
reaching to 4312.74 μN which is nearly twice of that in the ITZ. The mean force in the mastic is the lowest which is only 136.24 μN. For the mean indentation modulus, the change trend is similar to mean force. This result also indicates that the mechanical properties of ITZ are closer to that of aggregates rather than mastic. It is interesting to note that the order of modulus in cement-based materials is aggregates>cement paste>ITZ, while in asphalt mixture is aggregate> ITZ > mastic. It seems the ITZ is not the softest part in asphalt mixture. This is expected as the stiffness of ITZ differs in different composite materials. For instance, the ITZ between the cement paste and limestone aggregates is the softest part in concrete because of the “wall” effect and the micro bleeding effect [45] , whereas the ITZ between the lime-based matrix and brick fragments in lime-based mortar is harder than the surrounding mastic [15]. In view of the ITZ of asphalt concrete, the related researches are mainly based on the micromechanical model rather than the experimental analysis. From the publication reported by Huang et al. [25] and Zhu et al. [26, 27], the stiffness of ITZ in asphalt concrete is supposed to be between that of mastic and

aggregates. Their conclusions from micromechanical prediction are quite similar to our test results. However, the fact is that most cracks initiate and propagate along the interface between mastic and aggregate. This may result from the low strength of ITZ. In other words, it is possible that the elastic modulus of ITZ is higher than that of mastic, but the strength is lower. This may be because the mastic is a viscoelastic material in which the stress concentration is not easy generated. Although the tensile strength, shear strength, compressive strength of asphalt concrete can be measured at macro-scale, strength measurement on such a tiny area like ITZ is difficult, if possible, which will be further investigated in our future researches. Besides, it also should be noted that the precise crack location in asphalt concrete is still unclear, which is also needed to be carefully determined. The relevant researches on some other composites show that the cracks initiate and propagate either at the aggregate surface or in the ITZ [55-57]. Furthermore, the location of crack initiation in concrete is found to be influenced by the aggregate roughness. For example, Königsberger et al. conducted theoretical study and concluded that for aggregates with strong micro-roughness, or for aggregate types which react with the pore water solution, the ITZ failure should rather occur. While the ITZ-aggregate separation is likely to happen in the case of aggregates exhibiting rather smooth surfaces [17,58].
In addition, based on the statistical analysis results, it was found that the modulus standard
deviation of ITZ is the largest, reaching to 22.24 GPa which means the mechanical properties in ITZ is less stable than that in the aggregate (12.91 GPa) and the mastic (2.81 GPa). This variation can be explained by the fact that ITZ itself is a transition zone that presents a gradient nature. That is to say, the elastic modulus of regions closed to the aggregate is definitely higher than the elastic modulus of regions closed to the mastic. Therefore, the scatter of data is predictable. Here, we referred the statistical method used to deal with ITZ in cement concrete, see Refs. [15, 49, 51], they encountered the same issue.

sections.heading: 3.3 ITZ adjacent to different aggregates
sections.text:
To further understand the influence of different aggregates on the ITZ, the NI test was also
conducted on the basalt, ceramic and slag. Ceramic and slag are from bottom ash aggregates, which is the main output from MSWI residues. The NI test areas are illustrated in Fig. 18 and the thickness of ITZ is shown in Fig. 19. It can be seen that the thickness of ITZ is approximately 5-15 μm, 5-15 μm, 5-10 μm for ceramic, basalt, slag respectively. In addition, the mean modulus of ITZ was statistically analyzed and results are list in table 6. It can be seen that the mean modulus of ITZ in slag is the highest, followed by the ceramic, and ITZ in basalt has the lowest modulus. One of the possible reasons is that water absorption may have an impact on the properties of ITZ. Based on the water absorption test, the slag has the highest water absorption, from 12.25% to 20.91% for different particle size. For ceramic, the water absorption is lower, which is from 3.17% to 6.13%. The basalt has the lowest water absorption, from 1.70% to 2.41%. These results suggest that the modulus of ITZ adjacent to various aggregates can at least in part be explained by the differing water absorption. It is noteworthy that the property of ITZ is potentially affected by the physical and chemical properties of aggregates, particularly the aggregate roughness has a significant effect on the width of ITZs. It has been evidenced that the width of ITZ will increase with increasing aggregate roughness [19]. For example, based on Suchorzewski et al.’s observation, the width of ITZs around a very smooth aggregate is merely 2-3 μm. To figure out how those factors impact the ITZ, each of those factors will be further analyzed based on the

sections.heading: 3.4 Nano-scale Morphological properties
sections.text:
Figure 20 shows the SE image of asphalt mixture. It can be seen that there is a distinct
border between aggregates and ITZ, whereas the border between mastic and ITZ is not easily distinguished. In fact, precisely identifying the ITZ is difficult because of the limitation of qualitative description of SEM images. However, it is still can be seen that the mastic close to the aggregate surface is more compacted than the mastic far way. That is to say there exists a transition region where the structure transits from compacted to loose, this region can be called ITZ. It is well known that the secondary electron imaging collects low-energy (<50 ev) secondary electrons that are ejected from the k-shall of the specimen atoms by inelastic scattering interactions with beam electrons. The brightness of the image depends on the number of secondary electrons reaching the detector. If the sample’s surface is smooth, more secondary electrons are emitted from the sample, resulting in a brighter image, like the aggregate in Fig. 20. On the contrary, if the surface is uneven, like the asphalt mastic in Fig. 20, leading to a darker image. This is the reason why the compacted aggregate is brighter than mastic. The area located between the aggregate and the asphalt mastic is less compacted than the aggregate while is more compacted than the mastic according to the brightness, which means the area is an

interfacial transition zone between aggregates and mastic. The compacted ITZ can be explained by the chemical adhesion capability which is related to the polarity of the molecules present at the aggregate/asphalt surfaces. The closer to the aggregate, the stronger chemisorption may occur, resulting in the compacted region surrounded the aggregate, which can be identified as ITZ. However, the region far from the aggregate may get less chemisorption, leading to a loose structure and pores.

sections.heading: 3.5 Nano-scale chemical properties
sections.text:
EDS was conducted to scan the surface of asphalt mixture. According to the principle of EDS
(Fig. 21), it can be seen that the blue electron in an inner shell is kicked out by incident beam leaving an electron hole. The red electron from an outer shell then fills the hole and the difference in energy between the higher-energy shell and the lower energy shell may be released in the form of an X-ray. The counts, namely intensity, can reveal the relative amount change of elements. Figure 22 shows the change of elements amount from mastic to aggregates, and the asphalt mixture mainly consists of four elements, i.e. calcium (Ca), silicon (Si), carbon (C), and oxygen (O). The curves of Ca, Si and O show a fluctuating trend at a low level during the first 40 μm. Then, there is a remarkable increase from 40 μm to 52 μm. After that, the amount of O, Si and Ca keep fluctuation at a comparatively high level during the last 50 μm. However, the amount change of C represents a distinctly different trend from that of Ca, Si and O. It remains stable on the whole line. This graph illustrates that the mastic contains less Ca, Si and O than that of aggregates, and the element amount of ITZ is between that of mastic and aggregates. This phenomenon is compatible with the limestone, which mainly consists of calcium carbonate and silicon dioxide, therefore, the sensing probe can receive more X-rays when the aggregate is exposing to the electron beam. Besides, the tiny change in carbon may result from the small content of asphalt binder and the uneven mastic. In addition, it also can be seen that the thickness of ITZ is 12 μm (based on the chemical composition analysis results), which is accordance with the NI and FESEM results.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text:
The interfacial transition zone (ITZ) of asphalt mixture was investigated in this study. Its
mechanical, morphological, and chemical properties were studied by nanoindentation, EDS, and SEM, respectively. This research work has led to the following conclusions:
1. This study developed successful measuring methods for identifying the indentation
modulus of asphalt mixture based on nanoindentation. Due to the different mechanical properties of the aggregate and the mastic, the depth control mode rather than the load control mode is suggested. To ensure the effectiveness of test values, the roughness of sample’s surface, the maximum force of the nanoindentation, the distance between the adjacent points should all be taken into account before the determination of maximum indentation depth. In this study, 200 nm was chosen as the maximum indentation depth of test area.
2. Based on the NI, FESEM, and EDS, the existence of ITZ in asphalt mixture can be clearly
testified, and the thickness of ITZ is in the range of 5 μm to 20 μm. The mean modulus of ITZ is between that of mastic and aggregates. The element amount of calcium, silicon, oxygen on the ITZ is also between that on the mastic and aggregates. Besides, the morphology of ITZ further shows that the ITZ has a more compacted structure than mastic.
3. In terms of elastic modulus, ITZ seems not the softest part in the asphalt mixture. One
possible reason is that the closer to the aggregate, the stronger chemisorption may occur, resulting in the compacted region surrounded the aggregate. The water absorption of aggregate was predicted to have a potential effect on the mechanical properties of ITZ.
The theory of adhesion shows that different raw materials may cause different physical and
chemical actions between asphalt binders and aggregates. And then different structures and mechanical properties of ITZ will be formed. Therefore, the effect of aggregate properties, especially the roughness, on the ITZs needs to be paid more attention to. In addition, where the cracks precisely occur remains to be further investigated. It seems that cracks should rather occur between aggregate and ITZs in the case of smooth aggregate particles and between the mastic and ITZs for rough aggregate particles. However, in current, it is difficult to recognize where dose the crack precisely occur because of the limitation of test precision. To shed a light on this issue, the equipment of high measuring accuracy or a small-scale model are needed. Discussion along above lines will be further considered in our future researches.

Highlights
• A method based on nanoindentation technique was proposed to identify the elastic
modulus of interfacial transition zone (ITZ) in asphalt mixture
• It was found that the interfacial transition zone (ITZ) does exist in asphalt mixture and its
thickness is about 5-20 μm.
• The elastic modulus of ITZ in asphalt concrete is between that of mastic and aggregates,
because the microstructure of ITZ was more compacted than that of mastic.

metadata.abstractText: Identifying the nature of the region where the mastic meets the aggregate surface (interfacial transition zone, ITZ) is very helpful in understanding some mechanisms that govern the fracture behavior of asphalt pavement. However, it is rather difficult to identify and study ITZ by bulk techniques. In this study, nano-scale metrology techniques, including nanoindentation (NI), field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM), and energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS), were employed to explore the micromechanics, microstructure, and chemical properties of ITZ. Experimental results show that the ITZ exists in asphalt mixture and the thickness of ITZ is in the range from 5 μm to 20 μm. The modulus value of ITZ was found between that of the aggregate and the mastic. The microstructure of ITZ was observed to be more compacted than that of mastic. This study contributes significantly to the nano-scale characterization of ITZ in asphalt concrete, which can provide more realist inputs for the micromechanical models.
